text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen a while back I 
posted a tutorial on how to make sticky rice using

a traditional bamboo steamer which I still stand 
by is the best way to make sticky rice because

use the best result and it also infuses a nice 
bamboo aroma into the rice however that method

does require a bit of an advanced planning because 
the rice needs to soak for at least four hours so

it becomes a problem when I suddenly want sticky 
rice so I've been experimenting with a couple of

different ways I can make sticky rice without 
the need to soak it and I've come up with two

good methods that I'm going to share with you 
today the first method I call the steam the

bowl method and the second method is the rice 
cooker methods so let's go take a look at them

so first you want to start out by rinsing the 
rice a few times I've got here a cup and a half

of white glutinous rice make sure it's from 
Thailand because there are a few different

types and you just want to rinse it well with 
cold water a few times and this will wash away

the excess starch that will prevent the rice 
from being gummy when it's done and the first

rinse will be the water would be very cloudy 
and then progressively the second and the third

rinses the water will become clearer and clearer 
so what you're looking for is for the water to

be clear enough that you can actually see the 
rice through the water three to four times is

usually good enough on your final rinse you want 
to make sure you drain off the water really well

I like to use a stir the back of a strainer and 
just oh there's a little spout there make sure

all the water is gone because sticky rice is 
very sensitive to mushing so you have too much

residual water during the washing it will throw 
off your water to rice ratio and sticky rice is

really not very forgiving and then we're just 
going to transfer it into our heat proof Bowl

now this is a heat proof Bowl that we're going to 
cook the rice in and I like to use a flat bottom

bowl like this one and you'll see why in a second 
and then to this I'm going to add my water the

ratio is one part water two-thirds rice so with 
one and a half cup of rice I'm using one cup of

water here and sticky rice takes a lot less water 
than does regular white rice or always less water

than rice and also different kinds of Rice's will 
take different amounts of water there's something

called old crop rice and new crop rice and old 
crop rice has been dried out for a longer period

of time it'll take a little bit more water when 
you cook it you don't always know based on your

packaging what kind of rice you have so you may 
need a little bit more a little bit less than

me but I think starting with two thirds is a good 
ratio so basically we're going to take this bowl

and steam it and if you have a steamer great use 
it if you don't have a steamer then all you need

is a big pot with a lid that the bowl will fit in 
and then you can use one of these steamer racks

that you can get from an Asian grocery store 
for like a buck fifty and then set it in the

pot or you can't find this what you can do is 
you can make a donut foil a foil doughnut like

this which will prop up the bowl and I learned 
this trick during culinary school to prop up a

roast chicken actually so what you need is just 
four five four pieces before you may need less if

it's a heavy-duty one about about 16 inches long 
and then you're just going to scrunch it down and

you just have to make sure that your bowl sits 
on it okay you may need to adjust it a couple of

times and that's your makeshift steamer rack and 
just put it in there so in here I've got about

a little less than an inch of water you don't 
need a whole lot and I'm going to put my setup

in here and then bring this water to the oil so 
put the bowl into the pot after the waters come

to a full boil I like to turn the heat off while a 
off while I do this so I don't steam burn my hand

and then if you don't have one of these tongs 
to make sure you use an oven mitt when you go

in so you don't burn your hand and then we're 
going to let this steam for 25 minutes for one

and a half cup of rice that I have here if you 
have more rice you may need a little bit more

so after about 20 and 25 minutes it should 
be more or less done at this point but I've

turned it off but I'm just going to let 
it sit in there for another 10 minutes

or so this will let the steam settle and it 
would also allow any residual moisture in

there to be fully absorbed into the rice 
and the rice would be more nicely cooked

this method works because the heating is gentle 
now when you steam the bowl the water inside the

bowl never actually boils but it's hot enough that 
it gradually heats and cooks the rice so the rice

is cooked through while still maintaining that 
chewy texture if you take the bowl and transfer

all the content into a pot and you cook that 
directly on a stove what will happen is the

outside will start to mush before the inside cooks 
through now unlike white rice which can withstand

boiling water sticky rice is very sensitive to 
boiling water and it will mush if you do that

so the rice cooker method is pretty darn 
simple you just cook the rice in the rice

cooker but the same trick still apply you want 
to make sure you rinse the rice a few times and

you still want to make sure on your final 
rinse you rinse it really I mean you drain

it really really well and then we're going 
to use the same ratio of water one part rice

two-thirds water so I've got one cup here 
I'm going to add 2/3 cup of water into it

and it should come up off the rice just 
a little bit and then you just let it go

now some rice cookers are better at this than 
others the good ones are basically those that

have more gentle heating and doesn't vigorously 
boil the water for the same reason that the steam

the bowl method works now this little one only 
300 watt works great some fancy rice cookers

have actually have a special program for sticky 
rice and that program basically uses less power

so if you have a big powerful rice cookers it may 
not work as well and it may overcook the outside

of your rice a little bit so you just have to 
try it out and see if it works for you so the

rice cooker has already stopped but don't go in 
just yet let it sit for another 10 minutes what

happens is the rice cooker stops when there's no 
more liquid at the bottom and it senses a sudden

temperature rise from the from the pot and then it 
stops but there's still residual moisture that's

still in the rice so this rest time of 10 minutes 
allow that moisture to be fully absorbed into the

rice and you get rice that's more fully cooked and 
not so wet and this applies as well for when you

cook white rice in a rice cooker always let it 
sit for like 10 minutes or so before you go in

so here's our two different sticky Rice's that we 
cooked from the two different methods if you ask

me which one I prefer I would say the steam the 
bowl method because with the rice cooker method

there's always a layer of crispy rice at the 
bottom it might not happen emitting on which

rice cooker you have but I find this is much more 
reliable and as I said I think the traditional pre

soaked and steaming method is still the best way 
and if you haven't seen that you can click this

link for that original sticky rice tutorial 
and if you have another method that you use

I know some people can do it in a microwave I 
haven't tried that one out yet you can please

share it with us on our Facebook and I will see 
you next time for your next tip it's just tiny
